Generation I.Red: While lulling its enemies with its vacant look, this wily Pok é mon will use psychokinetic powers.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: While lulling its enemies with its vacant look, this wily Pok é mon will use psychokinetic powers.
Generation I.Yellow: Always tormented by headaches. It uses psychic powers, but it is not known if it intends to do so.
Generation I.Stadium: Appears unaware and totally vacant. However, if its chronic headache worsens, it starts exhibiting peculiar powers.

Generation II.Gold: It has mystical powers but doesn't recall that it has used them. That is why it always looks puzzled.
Generation II.Silver: If its chronic headache peaks, it may exhibit odd powers. It seems unable to recall such an episode.
Generation II.Crystal: The only time it can use its psychic power is when its sleeping brain cells happen to wake.
Generation II.Stadium 2: It has mystical powers but doesn't recall that it has used them. That is why it always looks puzzled. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) If its chronic headache peaks, it may exhibit odd powers. It seems unable to recall such an episode. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Psyduck uses a mysterious power. When it does so, this Pok é mon generates brain waves that are supposedly only seen in sleepers. This discovery spurred controversy among scholars.
Generation III.Sapphire: If it uses its mysterious power, Psyduck can't remember having done so. It apparently can't form a memory of such an event because it goes into an altered state that is much like deep sleep.
Generation III.Emerald: When its headache intensifies, it starts using strange powers. However, it has no recollection of its powers, so it always looks befuddled and bewildered.
Generation III.FireRed: It is constantly wracked by a headache. When the headache turns intense, it begins using mysterious powers.
Generation III.LeafGreen: While lulling its enemies with its vacant look, this wily Pok é mon will use psychokinetic powers.

Generation IV.Diamond: If its usual headache worsens, it starts exhibiting odd powers. It can't remember doing so, however.
Generation IV.Pearl: It never remembers using its odd powers, so it always tilts its head in puzzlement.
Generation IV.Platinum: Overwhelmed by enigmatic abilities, it suffers a constant headache. It sometimes uses mysterious powers.
Generation IV.HeartGold: It has mystical powers but doesn't recall that it has used them. That is why it always looks puzzled.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: If its chronic headache peaks, it may exhibit odd powers. It seems unable to recall such an episode.

Generation V.Black: Overwhelmed by enigmatic abilities, it suffers a constant headache. It sometimes uses mysterious powers.
Generation V.White: Overwhelmed by enigmatic abilities, it suffers a constant headache. It sometimes uses mysterious powers.
Generation V.Black 2: When headaches stimulate its brain cells, which are usually inactive, it can use a mysterious power.
Generation V.White 2: When headaches stimulate its brain cells, which are usually inactive, it can use a mysterious power.

Generation VI.X: It is constantly wracked by a headache. When the headache turns intense, it begins using mysterious powers.
Generation VI.Y: It has mystical powers but doesn't recall that it has used them. That is why it always looks puzzled.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Psyduck uses a mysterious power. When it does so, this Pokémon generates brain waves that are supposedly only seen in sleepers. This discovery spurred controversy among scholars.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: If it uses its mysterious power, Psyduck can't remember having done so. It apparently can't form a memory of such an event because it goes into an altered state that is much like deep sleep.

Generation VII.Sun: As a result of headaches so fierce they cause it to cry, it sometimes uses psychokinesis without meaning to.
Generation VII.Moon: This Pokémon is troubled by constant headaches. The more pain it's in, the more powerful its psychokinesis becomes.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: Using psychokinesis gives it a headache, so it normally passes the time spacing out and doing as little as possible.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: It has been found that its brain cells are 10 times more active when Psyduck is experiencing a headache.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: Always tormented by headaches. It uses psychic powers, but whether it intends to do so is not known.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: Always tormented by headaches. It uses psychic powers, but whether it intends to do so is not known.

Generation VIII.Sword: Psyduck is constantly beset by headaches. If the Pokémon lets its strange power erupt, apparently the pain subsides for a while.
Generation VIII.Shield: As Psyduck gets stressed out, its headache gets progressively worse. It uses intense psychic energy to overwhelm those around it.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: If its usual headache worsens, it starts exhibiting odd powers. It can't remember doing so, however.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It never remembers using its odd powers, so it always tilts its head in puzzlement.
Generation VIII.Legends: Arceus: Suffers perpetual headaches. If the agony grows too great, Psyduck's latent power erupts, contrary to Psyduck's intent. Ergo, I am exploring ways to ease the pain.

Generation IX.Scarlet: It is constantly wracked by a headache. When the headache turns intense, it begins using mysterious powers.
Generation IX.Violet: If its chronic headache peaks, it may exhibit odd powers. It seems unable to recall such an episode.
